author: By Jesse McKinley and Liam Stack
title: Cuomo Attacks Supreme Court, but Virus Ruling Is Warning to Governors
description: The court signaled that if unconstrained religious observance and public safety are sometimes at odds, then religious freedom should win out.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — As the coronavirus pandemic has deepened and darkened in recent months, the nation’s governors have taken increasingly aggressive steps to curb the current surge of infections, with renewed and expanded restrictions reaching into people’s homes, businesses, schools and places of worship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Barry
title: ‘Loser’: How a Lifelong Fear Bookended Trump’s Presidency
description: The president’s inability to concede the election is the latest reality-denying moment in a career preoccupied with an epithet.
content: In the now-distant Republican presidential primaries of 2016, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas handily won the Iowa caucuses. This was determined by a method that has lately come under attack but at the time was considered standard: elementary math.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Skolnick
title: She Dived More Than 300 Feet Under the Sea. Can She Go Deeper?
description: Alenka Artnik of Slovenia recently set a record in free diving. But her race to the bottom may not be over.
content: One morning this month, on the warm waters of the Red Sea off the coast of Egypt, Alenka Artnik donned a thin purple wet suit and a monofin, secured a four-pound weight around her neck, and fastened herself to a thin line she held loosely in one hand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Tingley
title: Sewage may offer early signs of coronavirus outbreaks.
description: People infected with the coronavirus may shed extremely high amounts of virus in their stool even before they show symptoms — if they ever do — suggesting that testing wastewater may offer health officials a way to spot budding community outbreaks early, researchers have found.
content: People infected with the coronavirus may shed extremely high amounts of virus in their stool even before they show symptoms — if they ever do — suggesting that testing wastewater may offer health officials a way to spot budding community outbreaks early, researchers have found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norman Mayersohn
title: ‘A Love Letter to Detroit,’ on Vellum and Chrome
description: An exhibition at the Detroit Institute of Arts highlights the relationship of art and car culture over the past 70 years.
content: Of the myriad treasures that might draw a sightseeing car lover to Detroit, one potential attraction is notably missing: a major public museum collection dedicated to the automobile. America’s Motor City offers many compelling reasons for a visit, but it really has nothing like the Petersen Automotive Museum in Los Angeles, the LeMay in Tacoma, Wash., or the well-known car displays in Reno, Indianapolis or Philadelphia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: N.F.L. Week 12 Predictions: Our Picks Against the Spread
description: Baltimore will be short-handed in a matchup with undefeated Pittsburgh — if the game is played — and Tampa Bay will need to be at its best to beat Kansas City.
content: A pair of blowouts on Thanksgiving served as a fairly entertaining start to a week that includes must-watch matchups like the Kansas City Chiefs against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and the Tennessee Titans against the Indianapolis Colts. Meanwhile, Baltimore’s delayed game against Pittsburgh could be anticlimactic considering the extent of the Ravens’ roster that will be missing. That’s if the game is played at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani
title: Paolo Gabriele, Pope’s Butler in ‘Vatileaks’ Scandal, Dies at 54
description: He admitted to stealing files and giving them to a journalist as a way to expose Vatican corruption and protect his boss, Benedict XVI.
content: ROME — Paolo Gabriele, who as the butler of Pope Benedict XVI was convicted of leaking internal Vatican documents to the news media in an extraordinary breach of church secrecy — the so-called Vatileaks scandal — died on Tuesday in Rome. He was 54.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom
title: Here’s What the Thanksgiving Parade Looked Like in Pandemic New York
description: The holiday ritual was limited to a block, with parts pretaped for television and barricades to keep people away. Still, a few curious spectators showed up.
content: It’s a yearly Thanksgiving Day tradition: Millions of spectators crammed onto long city blocks, hanging over barricades and balconies or pressed against the windows of towering office buildings to watch giant balloons, depicting cartoon characters like Pikachu, hovering just a few feet above the street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: In Praise of Janet Yellen the Economist
description: She never forgot that economics is about people.
content: It’s hard to overstate the enthusiasm among economists over Joe Biden’s selection of Janet Yellen as the next secretary of the Treasury. Some of this enthusiasm reflects the groundbreaking nature of her appointment. She won’t just be the first woman to hold the job, she’ll be the first person to have held all three of the traditional top U.S. policy positions in economics — chair of the Council of Economic Advisers, chair of the Federal Reserve and now Treasury secretary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nathan Burrow
title: How Not to Overspend This Black Friday
description: Have a list, a budget and some patience.
content: In a year characterized by an unremitting and unfortunate strangeness, it’s no surprise that Black Friday and Cyber Monday 2020 fit right in. Black Friday “preview” promotions started weeks early in mid-October, hot on the heels of Amazon Prime Day, which had been bumped from its traditional mid-July time slot to Oct. 13 and 14. Retailers began a rotating slate of sales, trumpeting that the best Black Friday deals were actually the early deals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘Kill It and Leave This Town’ Review: Grotesque, Bleak and Endless
description: One viewing is enough for this animated feature debut by the Polish director Mariusz Wilczynski.
content: It’s difficult to describe the Polish artist Mariusz Wilczynski’s debut film, “Kill It and Leave This Town,” because the animated feature — plotless, gloomy and surreal — is more a direct translation of feelings and sensations than a traditional work of storytelling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Video of Police Beating Black Man in Paris Fuels Debate on Filming Officers
description: Footage from security cameras and bystanders suggested the officers had lied about the beating, bolstering critics of a new bill that would restrict circulating videos of security forces.
content: PARIS — Video of police officers beating a Black man in Paris caused an outcry in France on Thursday, fueling criticism of a new bill that would place restrictions on sharing footage of security forces as the French authorities grapple with longstanding accusations of police racism and brutality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: One Nation, Under Maradona
description: Images from the life of one of soccer’s — and Argentina’s — biggest icons.
content: The Uruguayan writer Eduardo Galeano once called Diego Maradona “the most human of the gods.” Argentines were happy to edit that down, to the singular version of the last word.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Claudia Rankine Wishes More Writers Thought About Whiteness
description: “Racist ideas continue to shape our consciousness.”
content: When the poet and essayist, whose latest book is “Just Us,” finishes reading novels, she stores them in her guest room “or in a bag by the door to be given away.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Verses vs. Virus: What These Poets Laureate Are Thankful For
description: It’s been a difficult year in every corner of the land. But there are still neighbors and family, breathtaking landscapes and gratitude for the ‘bend without the break.’
content: As Americans gather for Thanksgiving in a nation battered and brought low by rampant disease and division, you may ask: What in this of all years do we have to be thankful for?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: England’s Lockdown Will Lift, but Many Pub Doors Will Stay Closed
description: Some Conservative lawmakers are calling Boris Johnson’s plans to continue restricting most of England’s bars and restaurants “authoritarian.”
content: LONDON — Under fire from critics over the economic and social cost of his coronavirus restrictions, Prime Minister Boris Johnson will bring a grueling, second, national lockdown in England to an end next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: What You Need to Know Now About Travel Insurance
description: A spate of new travel insurance policies have begun covering Covid-19, just as many international destinations begin to require it. Here’s what to look for.
content: When the pandemic struck, many travel insurance policies failed to cover Covid-19-related trip interruptions and cancellations, often because they excluded pandemics. But in the intervening months, the travel insurance industry has introduced a spate of new policies covering the disease just as many foreign destinations begin to require them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: ‘The Crown’ Stokes an Uproar Over Fact vs. Entertainment
description: Dramatic liberties in the latest season of the Netflix series, covering the turbulent 1980s, are annoying Britons who wrote of that period, even among those who disparage the royals.
content: LONDON — On a Saturday night in July 1986, a band of bureaucrats in raincoats — one contingent from Buckingham Palace, the other from 10 Downing Street — converged on a newsstand in a train station to snap up The Sunday Times, fresh off the presses with a bombshell headline: “Queen dismayed by ‘uncaring’ Thatcher.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Betty Jones, Founding Member of Limón Troupe, Dies at 94
description: She created the Desdemona role in José Limón’s best-known dance, “The Moor’s Pavane,” and became a respected teacher.
content: Betty Jones, a dancer known for memorable performances as an original member of José Limón’s famed company and later a respected dance teacher, died on Nov. 17 at her home in Honolulu. She was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jody Rosen
title: Crisscrossing the Country on Highways Big and Small
description: In “The National Road,” Tom Zoellner set out to discover what connects us as Americans at a time when divisions run deep.
content: THE NATIONAL ROAD: Dispatches From a Changing AmericaBy Tom Zoellner
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘My Psychedelic Love Story’ Review: On the Run With Timothy Leary
description: This Errol Morris documentary explores the relationship between the LSD guru and Joanna Harcourt-Smith, a woman who likened herself to Mata Hari.
content: To induce dread in a paranoiac, one need only invoke two acronyms: C.I.A. and LSD Along with a third and a fourth — U.F.O. and J.F.K. — these were key ingredients in the alphabet soup of conspiracy theory for more than half a century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Biden Brings the Gang Back Together
description: The Obama administration, Part 2, takes shape: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: The stock market surges as the transition moves ahead — and progressives have a clear message: Don’t forget about us. It’s Wednesday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Collins
title: Leonard Kamsler, a Dissecting Golf Photographer, Dies at 85
description: He pioneered the use of strobe photography to break down a golfer’s swing. He was also innovative, even crafty, in documenting P.G.A. tournaments for decades.
content: Leonard Kamsler, a photojournalist whose award-winning pictures of professional golf for nearly 50 years pushed the envelope of sports strobe photography as he amassed a trove of more than 200,000 images on the PGA Tour, died on Nov. 18 in Bethel, N.Y. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: N.F.L. Teams Are Restricting Crowds. The Dallas Cowboys Want More.
description: The team’s owner, Jerry Jones, is pursuing “a continued aggressive approach to having fans” at home games, even as coronavirus cases rise in the area around the stadium.
content: Texans love to brag that everything is bigger in their state. The land, the food and, this year, the size of the crowds at Dallas Cowboys games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Biden’s Cabinet: Who He’s Picked So Far
description: The makeup of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s inner circle is becoming clearer as the transition to his administration begins.
content: WASHINGTON — With the Trump administration having authorized the beginning of the formal transition process, President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. is slowly naming the individuals he hopes will guide him through his first term as president and help shape his thinking in the years ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: As N.F.L. crowds decline, the Dallas Cowboys keep the gates open.
description: Tens of thousands of fans are expected to be at AT&T Stadium in Arlington, Texas, on Thursday, when the Dallas Cowboys, as they have nearly every year since 1966, play at home on Thanksgiving, this time against the Washington Football Team.
content: Tens of thousands of fans are expected to be at AT&T Stadium in Arlington, Texas, on Thursday, when the Dallas Cowboys, as they have nearly every year since 1966, play at home on Thanksgiving, this time against the Washington Football Team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Midnight Ruling Exposes Rifts at a Supreme Court Transformed by Trump
description: The justices issued six opinions, several of them unusually bitter, in upholding challenges from churches and synagogues to state pandemic restrictions on religious services.
content: WASHINGTON — A few minutes before midnight on Wednesday, the nation got its first glimpse of how profoundly President Trump had transformed the Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim
title: Musical Travel Companions for a Year of Going Nowhere
description: The composer John Luther Adams combines immersive sound worlds with environmental activism.
content: In the early spring of 1989, the composer John Luther Adams set up camp near the confluence of the still-icy Tanana and Yukon rivers in Alaska. For days he held a solitary vigil, nursing heavy thoughts about his romantic and professional lives, in both of which he felt at a crossroads.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: E.U. Border Agency Accused of Covering Up Migrant Pushback in Greece
description: Frontex is under fire for letting Greece illegally repel migrants as the agency expands to play a more central role at the bloc’s external borders.
content: BRUSSELS — Mounting evidence indicates that the European Union’s border agency has been complicit in Greece’s illegal practice of pushing back migrants to Turkey, according to documents obtained by The New York Times and interviews with officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: The Most Popular Listings of October
description: All but one property on the month’s list are affordable only to the wealthy, or super-wealthy, in the case of the $88 million former home of Jeffrey Epstein, the convicted sex offender who died in jail last year.
content: The most popular listings on The New York Times’s Find a Home site in October all carried forward from the roundups of previous months; and all but one, a $359,000 co-op in Inwood, are expensive, from $1.295 million up to $88 million.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: As Surge Spreads, No Corner of Nation Is Spared
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, November 26, 2020.
content: “Covid didn’t care what I believed.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Biden Urges Unity: ‘We’re at War With the Virus, Not With One Another’
description: In an emotional address, he pleaded with Americans to “hang on” and cited the death of his son to say that he understood the loss in the nation.
content: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Wednesday delivered a raw but optimistic address to Americans in his first nonpolitical speech since winning the election, pleading with the nation to “hang on” and have hope even with the number of coronavirus cases spiking across the country and a hard winter on the horizon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Higgins and Sharon Otterman
title: 2nd Coronavirus Wave Hits Buffalo Area ‘With a Vengeance’
description: The positive test rate in Erie County has remained above 5 percent for almost two weeks.
content: BUFFALO, N.Y. — Over the past month, the number of coronavirus cases has increased tenfold in the upstate city of Buffalo and its surrounding suburbs. Hospitalizations already have surpassed the levels seen in the spring. And the Covid-19 hotline for Erie County, where Buffalo is situated, is getting “annihilated,” the health commissioner said, with 1,500 calls in one 24-hour period this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sulaiman Addonia
title: I Was a Child Refugee. Another War in Ethiopia Is Forcing More Children Into the Camps.
description: Abiy Ahmed, the country’s prime minister, has become the protagonist of a familiar story in Africa, which is written in blood by politicians in pursuit of their ideologies and power.
content: On Nov. 6, an Ethiopian friend messaged me on WhatsApp: Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed had ordered airstrikes against the regional government in the country’s northernmost Tigray Province, bordering Eritrea and Sudan. I looked up from my phone screen in a daze. My friend was raging at the return of violence. “Why don’t these men give us a break?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: Why This Billionaire Will Never Leave New York
description: For the cosmetics mogul and philanthropist Leonard Lauder, the city, with its museums, public transit and parks, is an explorer’s delight.
content: Why on God’s green earth would anyone choose to live somewhere besides New York City?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: South Korea reports its biggest one-day jump in cases in eight months.
description: South Korea reported 583 new cases of the coronavirus on Thursday, the biggest daily caseload since early March, as health officials struggled to contain a third wave.
content: South Korea reported 583 new cases of the coronavirus on Thursday, the biggest daily caseload since early March, as health officials struggled to contain a third wave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: N.J. Governor Wants Schools Open. Local Officials Have Other Ideas.
description: The tensions point to the difficulty governors across the Northeast have had in persuading districts to reopen — decisions that often require school boards to buck powerful unions.
content: SCOTCH PLAINS, N.J. — Gov. Philip D. Murphy has urged New Jersey school districts to open for some face-to-face instruction, repeatedly noting that the coronavirus spread among teachers and students was far lower than expected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: Military’s Role in Vaccine Will Be Strictly Behind the Scenes, Despite Trump’s Claims
description: While no troops will be administering shots or dropping off doses, scores of Defense Department employees are involved in the effort.
content: WASHINGTON — When President Trump talks about efforts to deliver the coronavirus vaccine to millions of Americans eager to return to their normal lives, he often says he is “counting on the military” to get it done.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen
title: Homes for Sale in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn
description: This week’s properties are in Manhattan Valley, Riverdale and Midwood.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Delta announces ‘quarantine free’ flights from Atlanta to Rome.
description: For the first time since the coronavirus pandemic swept across Europe and the United States, a pilot program will allow a limited number of passengers to travel across the Atlantic from Atlanta to Italy without having to quarantine upon arrival, according to a Delta Air Lines news release on Thursday.
content: For the first time since the coronavirus pandemic swept across Europe and the United States, a pilot program will allow a limited number of passengers to travel across the Atlantic from Atlanta to Italy without having to quarantine upon arrival, according to a Delta Air Lines news release on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Merkel outlines Germany’s plan to extend restrictions through December.
description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany on Thursday detailed measures to extend and tighten the country’s partial lockdown.
content: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany on Thursday detailed measures to extend and tighten the country’s partial lockdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Dr. Mary Fowkes, 66, Dies; Helped Science Understand the Pandemic
description: She performed autopsies in New York that found blood clots in vital organs, suggesting how much the virus spreads through the body.
content: Dr. Mary Fowkes, a neuropathologist at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan whose autopsies of Covid-19 victims early in the pandemic discovered serious damage in multiple organs — a finding that led to the successful use of higher doses of blood thinners to treat patients — died on Nov. 15 at her home in Katonah, N.Y., in Westchester County. She was 66.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Superintelligence’ Review: Melissa McCarthy Has to Save the World
description: In this comedy from Ben Falcone, McCarthy plays the world’s most average human, picked to save the world by an A.I. entity with the voice of James Corden.
content: In this new Melissa McCarthy comedy, directed by her husband and frequent collaborator Ben Falcone (who has a supporting role), she plays Carol, described by another character as “the most average person on earth.” This pronouncement catches the ear of a roving artificial intelligence — one that travels from smartphone to TV to rice cooker at will — which decides on Carol, a former Silicon Valley star turned do-gooder, as its test subject.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judge Glock
title: Thanksgiving Is a Celebration of Freedom
description: The origins of the national holiday have little to do with Pilgrims and Indians.
content: As with so much in our lives, Thanksgiving has become a cultural battleground. Politicians and pundits debate whether we should use the day to memorialize the tragedy of the Indians or to celebrate the new liberties of the Pilgrims in America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Wedding Rings Lost in Shipwreck Will Be Returned to Migrant Couple
description: The owners of the two rings, which were found in a backpack in the Mediterranean, survived the capsizing of their vessel as they crossed from Libya to Europe.
content: The red backpack had been floating for two weeks in the central Mediterranean between Libya and Italy when a rescue boat came across it. Inside, along with clothes and some notes in Arabic, was a simple treasure: two wedding rings engraved with hearts and the names Ahmed and Doudou.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Senate Democrats Face Power Struggle for Top Judiciary Job
description: Senators Richard J. Durbin and Sheldon Whitehouse are vying to be the top Democrat on the panel that controls judicial nominations, reflecting a broader debate among activists about how to wield power.
content: WASHINGTON — As soon as Senator Richard J. Durbin of Illinois learned officially on Monday that there would be a Democratic opening at the top of the Judiciary Committee, he was on the phone to his colleagues trying to nail down their support for the position.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Why Is My Uncle So Mad About Student Debt Forgiveness?
description: A reader wonders how to talk to a salty boomer about progress.
content: I am a recent college graduate. I am also drowning in student debt. On my salary, there is no way I can save money or think about buying an apartment while I make large payments on these loans. This will continue for 15 years at least. The pandemic “pause” on payments has been a huge relief. And I’m excited by the possibility of our new president doing something to forgive some of my student debt. But when I talked to my uncle about this, he got angry and took it very personally: “No one forgave my student loans!” I didn’t know how to respond or if I should have. But it’s awkward now. Any advice?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: U.S. Border Agency Settles With 2 Americans Detained for Speaking Spanish
description: In a video of the 2018 incident in Havre, Mont., a Border Patrol agent is heard telling the two American women he detains that speaking Spanish in the small city is “very unheard-of.”
content: Two women who were detained in a small town in Montana after a Border Patrol agent heard them speaking Spanish at a convenience store have settled for an undisclosed amount after filing a lawsuit against U.S. Customs and Border Protection, the A.C.L.U. of Montana said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: Happy Thanksgiving to our American readers. Our recommended books this week include a presidential memoir, a couple of looks at the culture of big tech (in Silicon Valley and in rural China), a remembrance of a road trip with Jorge Luis Borges and a graphic novel about Syrian refugees in America, among others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari and Michael Corkery
title: New Jersey’s American Dream Mall Is Still Waiting to Fully Open
description: After more than 15 years, the Meadowlands complex began a phased opening in late 2019, but before customers could shop at its stores the pandemic hit and completely upended the retail industry.
content: When the American Dream mall, a massive shopping and entertainment complex next to MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., finally opened its doors to the public last October, its owner, the Triple Five Group, was eager to prove naysayers wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise
title: Families Have Been Torn Apart by Politics. What Happens to Them Now?
description: Unlike 2016, when conflicts emerged over political choices, this time many are centered on the legitimacy of the result itself.
content: Tho Nguyen’s parents, who immigrated from Vietnam, were always Republican. They are Catholic and oppose abortion. Four years ago they voted for Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: This Wrongly Convicted Man Spent 25 Thanksgivings in Prison
description: This holiday, he says he’s thankful. Are you?
content: In 1995, I was a 25-year-old Brooklyn father of a one-and-a-half-year-old son. I had recently joined The Times and had become the paper’s youngest newsroom department head since a man named Lester Markel was named Sunday editor in 1923.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Ethiopia’s Leader Escalates Assault on Tigray Region, Putting Civilians at Risk
description: Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed said that a deadline for the region’s dissident leaders to surrender had lapsed. The conflict threatens to destabilize the entire Horn of Africa.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — Just over three weeks ago, Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed of Ethiopia unleashed his military forces in an attempt to subdue the country’s northern region of Tigray, whose rebellious governing party was until recently the dominant force in Ethiopia’s central government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Splitting 5 to 4, Supreme Court Backs Religious Challenge to Cuomo’s Virus Shutdown Order
description: Justice Amy Coney Barrett played a decisive role in the decision, which took the opposite approach of earlier court rulings related to coronavirus restrictions in California and Nevada.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court late Wednesday night barred restrictions on religious services in New York that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo had imposed to combat the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Sinker
title: The Birds Are Outside
description: One bird feeder became two, then three. Months passed.
content: Me, my wife, our teenager and our 5-year old, we knew nothing about birds before the lockdown sent us inside in March. Our cramped home was suburban-convenient before the pandemic hit, nestled a few blocks from a school we don’t go in and a train downtown we won’t ride, and now it is just small.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Turkey Jails Hundreds for Life Over 2016 Coup Attempt
description: Those accused of being ringleaders were among the many sentenced in one of the most important mass trials relating to the plot.
content: ISTANBUL — A Turkish court sentenced the accused ringleaders and hundreds of others suspected of involvement in the failed 2016 coup to multiple life terms on Thursday, at the culmination of one of the most important mass trials in the plot to overthrow President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hailey Fuchs
title: New Rule Would Allow U.S. to Use More Methods for Executions
description: The rule, which would permit methods including firing squads and electrocution, comes as the administration rushes to execute five more prisoners before President Trump’s term ends.
content: The Justice Department has created new regulations allowing for the use of more methods for federal executions, including firing squad and electrocution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Mosul’ Review: In Iraq, This Time It’s Personal
description: A rogue Iraqi SWAT team fights the Islamic State in Matthew Michael Carnahan’s action thriller.
content: “Mosul” dramatizes a 2017 story in The New Yorker that chronicled a self-directed Iraqi SWAT team’s efforts to fight the Islamic State. Counting both Condé Nast and the “Avengers: Endgame” directors Anthony and Joe Russo among its producers, this Netflix movie balances admirable ambition (it’s an American film, but the characters speak Arabic) with the cruder goosing strategies and red-meat dialogue of a revenge picture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Stardust’ Review: A Week With David Bowie, Unaccompanied by His Music
description: A more accurate title for this movie, set in the early ’70s, would be “Johnny Flynn Sings Jacques Brel.”
content: This motion picture, in which an unusually coiffed performer, accompanying himself on acoustic guitar, sings some Jacques Brel songs, purports to be a story about David Bowie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: The Rotting of the Republican Mind
description: When one party becomes detached from reality.
content: In a recent Monmouth University survey, 77 percent of Trump backers said Joe Biden had won the presidential election because of fraud. Many of these same people think climate change is not real. Many of these same people believe they don’t need to listen to scientific experts on how to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Venezuela Raids Food Charity, Interrupting Meals for Children
description: The charity, Feed the Solidarity, often provides the only meals children receive each day. The government accuses it of subversion, with no evidence.
content: CARACAS, Venezuela — Government agents have raided the offices and frozen the bank accounts of a major Venezuelan food charity, threatening a lifeline for thousands of children during one of the world’s deepest humanitarian crises.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: This long Thanksgiving weekend, check out a great concert, a craft show for kids and a reboot that’s better than the original.
content: Every Monday and Friday, Margaret offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Missing ‘The Nutcracker’? How to Get Your Holiday Fix at Home
description: Many seasonal mainstays have been reimagined for online viewing this year. Here are some of our favorites, from “A Christmas Carol” to Handel’s “Messiah.”
content: We all have our holiday traditions. Maybe yours is seeing the Rockettes at Radio City Music Hall and gazing at the Rockefeller Center tree, all done up in lights. Well, this year “The Christmas Spectacular” is canceled, and that Norway spruce is just sorry looking (though organizers swear the tree will be beautiful by the time of its lighting on Dec. 2).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Gratitude in Six Words, From Our Readers
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: Last week, I invited readers to send us six words describing what made them thankful in 2020. It’s a form of writing — the six-word memoir — popularized by the author Larry Smith.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Politi
title: In Argentina, Maradona’s Death Sets Off a Vivid Display of Public Grief
description: For many Argentines, Diego Maradona, who died on Wednesday, was no mere soccer superstar. “I feel like a member of my family just died,” said one.
content: BUENOS AIRES — People laid flowers and lit candles below the mural of Diego Maradona outside the stadium here that bears his name. A man cried inconsolably.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pope Francis
title: Pope Francis: A Crisis Reveals What Is in Our Hearts
description: To come out of this pandemic better than we went in, we must let ourselves be touched by others’ pain.
content: In this past year of change, my mind and heart have overflowed with people. People I think of and pray for, and sometimes cry with, people with names and faces, people who died without saying goodbye to those they loved, families in difficulty, even going hungry, because there’s no work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Maradona, Covid-19, Macron: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Taylor Swift Illuminates ‘Folklore’ in a Stripped-Down Studio Concert
description: Playing her latest album for the first time with two collaborators who helped make it, Swift heightens the songs’ sense of pristine contemplation.
content: “Folklore: The Long Pond Studio Sessions” is straightforward and cozy. Taylor Swift and her two main collaborators and producers for her album “Folklore” — Aaron Dessner (from the National) and Jack Antonoff (a linchpin of Bleachers and fun., and a producer for Lorde, Lana Del Rey and others) — play through the album’s 17 songs at Dessner’s Long Pond Studio, a rural haven in Hudson, N.Y. Conversations between the collaborators introduce each song; birds and insects chirp.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: New Jersey’s governor wants schools open. Local officials have other ideas.
description: Gov. Philip D. Murphy has urged New Jersey school districts to open for some face-to-face instruction, repeatedly noting that the coronavirus spread among teachers and students was far lower than expected.
content: Gov. Philip D. Murphy has urged New Jersey school districts to open for some face-to-face instruction, repeatedly noting that the coronavirus spread among teachers and students was far lower than expected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danya Issawi
title: Halima Aden Chooses Faith Over Fashion
description: The well-known model shared via Instagram that she’s taking a break to set some boundaries in the industry.
content: Halima Aden, a model, is taking a step back from the fashion industry to focus on herself and her faith.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually.
content: If your children have had their fill of turkey and tradition, you can offer them more exotic fare — the cinematic kind — from nations far away. From Saturday through Dec. 6, the Brooklyn Academy of Music is presenting a cultural tasting menu in the form of the Best of BAMkids Film Festival 2020, an hourlong video-on-demand program of short animated works from 10 countries. For families who couldn’t go to the full festival in February, this virtual event presents 12 highlights to sample at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Geoffrey Palmer, Judi Dench’s Sitcom Co-Star, Is Dead at 93
description: Their show “As Time Goes By” was a hit in Britain and had a following in the U.S. “When you acted with him,” Ms. Dench said, “you’d just feel very safe.”
content: Geoffrey Palmer, a British character actor whose career peaked during the long run of “As Time Goes By,” the romantic BBC sitcom in which he and Judi Dench played lovers reunited after 38 years apart, died on Nov. 5 at his home in Buckinghamshire, near London. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: A Soaring Monument to Beauty in China Is Stirring Passions. Mostly Anger.
description: As China fights to end extreme poverty while also recovering from the economic damage of the coronavirus, the supposed wisdom of building huge statues in poorer areas to grow tourism is coming under harsh scrutiny.
content: JIANHE, China — Yang Asha smiled serenely down at the craggy emerald landscape, her hand outstretched in welcome. She appeared unmoved by the fierce condemnation her presence has ignited in China — she is, after all, made of gleaming stainless steel and bigger than the Statue of Liberty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Oh, Brother! Tears for Trump
description: No arguments — or turkey — this Thanksgiving. Just a cocktail.
content: This Thanksgiving, I’m going to make myself a French 75 and toast the end of a very bad, horrible, no-good year. I’ll be the only one in our family following Dr. Fauci’s advice to “bite the bullet” and skip our large holiday gathering. No doubt, my Trump-loving family will pour one out for the president. In that spirit, my brother, Kevin, offers the following threnody for Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wudan Yan
title: Their Teeth Fell Out. Was It Another Covid-19 Consequence?
description: People who already have dental problems may see them aggravated by encounters with the coronavirus, some experts suggest.
content: Earlier this month, Farah Khemili popped a wintergreen breath mint in her mouth and noticed a strange sensation: a bottom tooth wiggling against her tongue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. Hershey Jr
title: James D. Wolfensohn, Who Led the World Bank for 10 Years, Dies at 86
description: He was a force on Wall Street before taking the reins of the bank in 1995, then proceeded to shake it up. He did the same at both Carnegie Hall and the Kennedy Center.
content: James D. Wolfensohn, who escaped a financially pinched Australian childhood to become a top Wall Street deal maker and a two-term president of the World Bank, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Trump Brought Back Michael Flynn for the Finale, Fallon Says
description: “Seriously, there’s a name from the past,” Jimmy Fallon said of Flynn on Wednesday. “Even Michael Flynn was like, ‘Damn, I totally forgot about Michael Flynn.’”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Many of us are stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: What We’re Thankful for This Year
description: Health, family and the internet.
content: Welcome. It’s Thanksgiving, and for many of us it’ll be smaller and quieter than in years past. I recommend taking a minute to read Mark Vanhoenacker on how he’s fending off sadness at not being with family for the holiday; it might broaden your perspective. And check out Sam Sifton on adding new flavors to your Thanksgiving dinner — in the absence of a crowd, you too might veer from the traditional menu and “play the deep cuts.” (I like the sound of a pumpkin layer cake with caramel buttercream.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Prevost and Anne Mancuso
title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: This week’s featured properties are a five-bedroom house in Bronxville, N.Y., and a three-bedroom in Rowayton, Conn.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: A Fight Over Agriculture Secretary Could Decide the Direction of Hunger Policy
description: The delicate proxy clash has pitted Democrats eager to emphasize issues like hunger and nutrition against traditionalists who believe the department should represent rural America.
content: An unlikely fight is breaking out over President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s choice for agriculture secretary, pitting a powerful Black lawmaker who wants to refocus the Agriculture Department on hunger against traditionalists who believe the department should be a voice for rural America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: A Thanksgiving Myth Debunked: People Aren’t Fighting About Politics
description: Smaller gatherings mean fewer chances to talk to relatives you disagree with. But most Americans prefer to skip partisan debates altogether, no matter how big the turkey.
content: With millions of Americans choosing not to visit loved ones this Thanksgiving out of caution over the coronavirus, a lot of small rituals will get passed over in the process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Babe in the Woods
description: Neville Fogarty stretches the bounds of reality.
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — First, on behalf of the New York Times Games team, I would like to wish you all a peaceful holiday, no matter how you might be celebrating it this year. We know that there are many crossword puzzles and online games to be played, and we are thankful that you chose The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Immanuel Quickley’s Path to the Knicks Started at the Foul Line
description: Quickley, a guard out of Kentucky, is an exceptional free throw shooter, a skill he learned from his mother. He had the third highest free-throw percentage in Division I last season.
content: Even with all of the basketball skills that are hyped and parsed at an N.B.A. draft — scoring, 3-point shooting, rebounding, rim protection, playmaking — it was striking to hear television analysts so focused on Immanuel Quickley’s foul shooting last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: Two Texas Men Charged With Scheme to Sell 50 Million Nonexistent N95 Masks
description: The Houston-area men charged a foreign government more than $317 million for the masks, about five times the public list price, the authorities said.
content: Two Houston-area men have been indicted by a federal grand jury on charges that they negotiated a deal to sell 50 million nonexistent N95 masks to a foreign government in an attempt to defraud it out of over $317 million, federal officials said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: The Heir to the Manning Quarterback Legacy Isn’t on TikTok
description: Arch Manning, 16, nephew of Peyton and Eli, has a protective family to steer him from the perils of fame and expectation. And a grandfather, Archie, who texts him reminders to “have fun.”
content: Last summer, while reading a list of Louisiana’s top college football recruiting prospects, Archie Manning noticed that only one of the high school players did not have a Twitter account. It happened to be his grandson and namesake Arch, a nephew of Peyton and Eli.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court blocks New York’s virus-imposed limits to religious services.
description: The Supreme Court late Wednesday barred restrictions on religious services in New York that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo had imposed to combat the coronavirus.
content: The Supreme Court late Wednesday barred restrictions on religious services in New York that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo had imposed to combat the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Zappa’ Review: Portrait of a Rock Star and a Nation’s Hero
description: The documentary, directed by Alex Winter, portrays the musician and composer Frank Zappa as a sort of noble.
content: This documentary directed by Alex Winter opens with a portrait of the ostensibly outrageous musician Frank Zappa in a moment of nobility. It is footage shot in Prague in 1991, two years before Zappa’s death from cancer at the age of 52.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Camille Martin
title: In the Face of Challenges,‘Thinking of Yourself in a Higher Light’
description: For New Yorkers starting new chapters, the struggles of the coronavirus pandemic took on additional intensity.
content: Last fall, Demetria Mack was elated to be starting at Howard University. She was not only gaining the independence of a college student, but as she moved into her dorm room, she was also entering a new chapter in her journey out of foster care.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Edward J. Perkins, 92, Dies; First Black U.S. Envoy to South Africa
description: He also held ambassadorial postings in Liberia and Australia and, as director general, helped diversify the elite, mostly white Foreign Service.
content: When Edward J. Perkins was a student at a segregated school in Pine Bluff, Ark., his history teacher taught the class about the brutal racial oppression in South Africa. It was even worse, the students were told, than what they as Black people were experiencing in the American South.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: In Need of a Film About Romantic Possibility? Try ‘In the Mood for Love’
description: Wong Kar-wai’s influential drama, along with his “Chungking Express,” are part of a new retrospective of the Hong Kong director’s work.
content: Gateway Movies offers ways to begin exploring directors, genres and topics in film by examining a few streaming movies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Rothman
title: A Turkey Recipe for 2020
description: How to feel better about this horrible year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Wolf
title: This Lockdown, England’s Theaters Know What to Do Online
description: The first coronavirus shutdown caught playhouses unawares, but they learned lessons that stood them in good stead when the shutters came down again.
content: LONDON — What a difference a lockdown makes. By way of proof, consider the terrific lineup of actresses brought together for “Little Wars,”  an imaginative if overly arch play by the American writer Stephen Carl McCasland that is streaming online through Dec. 3. Its run finishes the day after England’s second coronavirus shutdown is scheduled to be lifted, at which point theaters in most regions will, with luck, be open again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith, Holland Cotter, Jason Farago and Siddhartha Mitter
title: Best Art Books of 2020
description: The art critics of The Times select their favorites from this year’s crop of art books.
content: The long stretches of pandemic lockdown this year have afforded the chance to spend as much time reading about art as looking at it, which may account for the number of text-intensive recommendations on our lists. At the same time, with access to “live” art still limited, images on the pages of some books below will let you create your own private museums-at-home, and they’ll be pretty glorious. — Holland Cotter
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Can the Mainstream Catch Up to Rico Nasty?
description: The 23-year-old Maryland rapper has built a cult following with her mixtapes of playful but bruising scream-rap. Now she’s releasing her major-label debut.
content: When the rapper Rico Nasty talks about falling in love at first sight, she doesn’t mean with an individual, but with a feeling. She’s talking about her first time on a real stage, and not even as a performer, but as a hanger-on in the wings. Still, that night, everything was moving in dreamy slow motion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: In ‘This Is Your Time,’ Ruby Bridges Urges a New Generation to Keep Fighting
description: The trailblazer’s best seller is intended for a middle grade audience, but her message of persistence is relevant to people of all ages.
content: VISIBLE GEM This has been a bittersweet month for Ruby Bridges, the civil rights icon who was the first Black student to integrate an all-white school in New Orleans. On Nov. 10, four days before the 60th anniversary of her first day at William Frantz Elementary, Bridges’ mother died at the age of 86. Lucille Bridges was known for escorting her 6-year-old to school under the guard of federal marshals while protesters chanted and threw eggs. This went on for a full school year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry and Nicole Perlroth
title: Patients of a Vermont Hospital Are Left ‘in the Dark’ After a Cyberattack
description: A wave of damaging attacks on hospitals upended the lives of patients with cancer and other ailments. “I have no idea what to do,” one said.
content: At lunchtime on Oct. 28, Colleen Cargill was in the cancer center at the University of Vermont Medical Center, preparing patients for their chemotherapy infusions. A new patient will sometimes be teary and frightened, but the nurses try to make it welcoming, offering trail mix and a warm blanket, a seat with a view of a garden.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Times readers shared what they’re thankful for in six words.
description: Last week, David Leonhardt invited readers of his Morning newsletter to send six words describing what made them thankful in 2020. Here is a selection of their responses:
content: Last week, David Leonhardt invited readers of his Morning newsletter to send six words describing what made them thankful in 2020. Here is a selection of their responses:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: South Korean Mastermind of Exploitation Chat Rooms Gets 40 Years in Prison
description: Cho Joo-bin was convicted of blackmailing young women into making sexually explicit video clips that he sold online.
content: SEOUL, South Korea — He preyed on young women looking for high-paying jobs through social media platforms. He lured them into making sexually explicit video clips, promising big payouts. Then, prosecutors said, once he got ahold of the compromising images, he used them as blackmail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaya Laterman
title: They Were Worried About Finances. This Is How They Got Help.
description: “I have never seen this much anxiety and fear about money,” one financial counselor said.
content: The prolonged pandemic has forced many New Yorkers to reassess their finances, bringing wrenching decisions on how to get by despite lost jobs or reduced work hours. Others have managed to save more than usual, as quarantine restrictions have pared their spending.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eleanor Davis
title: Giving Thanks in 2020
description: It’s been a difficult year. It’s OK to keep it simple.
content: It’s been a difficult year. It’s OK to keep it simple.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Best Books to Give This Year
description: What better way to spread joy than with books? We've rounded up 62 new titles, from thrillers to cookbooks to photography books and more, for every type of reader.
content: What better way to spread joy than with books? We've rounded up 62 new titles, from thrillers to cookbooks to photography books and more, for every type of reader.
source.name: The New York Times

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This week’s featured properties are a five-bedroom house in Bronxville, N.Y., and a three-bedroom in Rowayton, Conn.
content: This week’s featured properties are a five-bedroom house in Bronxville, N.Y., and a three-bedroom in Rowayton, Conn.
source.name: The New York Times

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This week’s properties are in Manhattan Valley, Riverdale and Midwood.
content: This week’s properties are in Manhattan Valley, Riverdale and Midwood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade Is Scaled Down in a Pandemic
description: The threat of the coronavirus led planners of the annual parade in New York City to drastically revise plans, including reducing the route to a single block down 34th Street, near the flagship department store.
content: The threat of the coronavirus led planners of the annual parade in New York City to drastically revise plans, including reducing the route to a single block down 34th Street, near the flagship department store.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Perfecting the Art of Listening
description: Readers discuss breaking bad habits and the need to be vulnerable.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Nov. 26, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Nov. 26, 2020.
content: An article on Sunday about the Kolyma Highway in Russia misstated the surname of a rocket scientist who survived political imprisonment and later helped put the first man in space. He is Sergei Korolev, not Kovalyov.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What to Do About Student Loan Debt?
description: Readers offer suggestions that go part way to loan forgiveness.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
